The critics of the Health Care Act have long argued that the new regulations they have put in place, especially those relating to business, would hinder employment - or, in a language more explosive than the campaign, would be "job killer." The critics received what appeared to be a push when the Congressional Budget Office - a non-partisan number writer in Congress - issued a report on the subject in February 2014. The Community Bureau expects that by 2017, there will be about 2 million fewer workers than it will be in the absence of the law. OIOS said that this number would increase to about 2.5 million by 2024. However, most critics of the law overlooked some critical facts when citing these figures. Why "murder" is the wrong word, the biggest problem with Teal'c describing the findings of the Central Bureau is that he used the word "murder." This is inaccurate because it indicates that employers will separate 2.5 million people, or because businesses will not create so many jobs. This is not what the report said, but the decline will essentially be achieved by voluntary choices by workers, not by employers.
